citations.narrative:
The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care for vaccinations. Of the 32 adult dogs, 7 are not up to date on all
three of the required vaccinations (distemper, parvovirus, and rabies). The current Program of Vet Care prescribes for the
vaccinations to be performed yearly.
- Adult male Poodle “Courage” #4983 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus vaccine
is current.
- Adult female Cavalier “Little Red” #7451 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus
vaccine is current.
- Adult female Poodle “Pollyanna” #7247 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus
vaccine is current.
- Adult female Havanese “Patience” #6639 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus
vaccine is current.
- Adult male Havanese “Warrior” #6657 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus
vaccine is current.
- Adult female Yorkie “Ollie” #5126 has no history of ever receiving a distemper/parvovirus vaccine. The rabies vaccine is
current.
- Adult female Yorkie cross “Molly” #6721 has no history of ever receiving a distemper/parvovirus vaccine. The rabies
vaccine is current.
Distemper, parvovirus, and rabies are life-threatening diseases and, if contracted, may cause pain, distress, and suffering.
It is also important for breeding females to be vaccinated as they will pass immunity to their offspring through their milk.
Correct by vaccinating for distemper, parvovirus, and rabies in accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending
Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer recommendations.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by May 25, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care for vaccinations. Of the 32 adult dogs, 7 are not up to date on all 
three of the required vaccinations (distemper, parvovirus, and rabies). The current Program of Vet Care prescribes for the 
vaccinations to be performed yearly. 
 
- Adult male Poodle “Courage” #4983 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus vaccine 
is current. 
- Adult female Cavalier “Little Red” #7451 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus 
vaccine is current.  
- Adult female Poodle “Pollyanna” #7247 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus 
vaccine is current. 
- Adult female Havanese “Patience” #6639 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus 
vaccine is current. 
- Adult male Havanese “Warrior” #6657 has no history of ever receiving a rabies vaccine. The distemper/parvovirus 
vaccine is current. 
- Adult female Yorkie “Ollie” #5126 has no history of ever receiving a distemper/parvovirus vaccine. The rabies vaccine is 
current. 
- Adult female Yorkie cross “Molly” #6721 has no history of ever receiving a distemper/parvovirus vaccine. The rabies 
vaccine is current. 
 
Distemper, parvovirus, and rabies are life-threatening diseases and, if contracted, may cause pain, distress, and suffering. 
It is also important for breeding females to be vaccinated as they will pass immunity to their offspring through their milk. 
Correct by vaccinating for distemper, parvovirus, and rabies in accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending 
Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer recommendations. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by May 25, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee

and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
